documents.content:
CSA Unit 24 - Air Handling
Chapter 1                                           
Air Handling for Gas 
Technicians
Since air movement has a significant impact on building comfort and 
safety, the gas technician/fitter must understand air handling. Gas 
technicians/fitters should be familiar with the building and gas codes, 
provincial regulations, and industry standards that govern air handling. In 
addition, they should have a good understanding of the effect of the 
building as a system on air movement, the process of heat transfer, and 
the qualities and characteristics of air.
MK by Mike Kapin
Created
Copywrite 2025
Learning Objectives
Identify Codes and Standards
Identify codes and industry standards that apply to air flow
Understand Heat Transfer
Describe the process of heat transfer and heating equipment 
capacity
Air Properties
Describe the properties and characteristics of air
Service Procedures
Describe service and adjustment procedures for air handling units
Key Terminology
Abbreviation (Symbol)
Definition
H
The total heat contained in a 
substance, which is the sum of sensible 
heat and latent heat
The process of heat moving from one 
source to another
Moisture in the air that comes from 
water that has evaporated into the air
>
The volume of a substance per unit of 
the substance
The intensity of heat, measured with a 
dry bulb thermometer
V
The amount of space that a three-
dimensional figure occupies
Gas Trade Training and Red Seal Alignment
You can use the CSA Group Gas Trade Training materials as resources to help you prepare for the Red Seal Gasfitter – Class B 
exam. For more information on how these materials align with the 2014 national standard for the occupation of Gasfitter - 
Class B, please review an expanded reference matrix at https://store.csagroup.org/.
Codes and Industry Standards
The gas technician/fitter must be familiar with the requirements contained in CSA B149.1 as well as the appropriate provincial 
building codes and industry standards. CSA Group publishes two standards directly relevant to air handling equipment:
CAN/CSA F280
Standard for determining the required capacity of 
residential space heating and cooling appliances
CAN/CSA F326
Standard for residential mechanical ventilation 
systems
HRAI and Industry Support
The Heating, Refrigeration and Air Conditioning Institute of Canada 
(HRAI) provides certification courses and technical manuals that address 
the requirements of building codes and industry standards for residential 
and small commercial heating, ventilating, and air conditioning systems, 
as they apply to selection and installation of these systems.
In addition to knowing building code requirements, the gas 
technician/fitter must consult with municipal building departments for 
local bylaws pertaining to heating and ventilation.
Relevant Codes and Standards
National Building Code of Canada (NBC)
National Building Code that forms the basis for codes written in 
Canadian provinces
National Research Council Canada (NRC): www.nrc-cnrc.gc.ca
Ontario Building Code (OBC)
Building code used in Ontario
Contains some additional requirements beyond CAN/CSA F326
Ontario Ministry of Municipal Affairs and Housing: 
www.mah.gov.on.ca
British Columbia Building Code (BCBC)
Building code used in British Columbia that contains some 
prescriptive requirements different from those of the NBC and 
CAN/CSA F326 (however, CAN/CSA F326 is permitted as an 
alternative.)
British Columbia Codes: www.bccodes.ca
R-2000 Standard
An industry-endorsed technical performance standard for energy 
efficiency, indoor air tightness quality, and environmental 
responsibility in home construction
Technical requirements comply with CAN/CSA F326, but include 
additional requirements for energy performance, qualifications of 
the installer and designer, and record-keeping
A voluntary standard administered by Natural Resources Canada 
(NRCan): www.nrcan.gc.ca/home
National Building Code of Canada (NBC)
Two sections of the NBC contain clauses that apply to air handlers:
Part 6
•
Heating, Ventilating and Air-Conditioning
•
Covers technical requirements
•
Applies to all buildings
Part 9
•
Housing and Small Buildings
•
Covers prescriptive requirements
•
Applies to buildings of three or fewer stories and with a 
building area not exceeding 600 m²
NBC Application Areas
Besides general clauses dealing with scope, application, definitions, and plans and 
specifications, Parts 6 and 9 apply to design and installation of:
Ventilation
Requirements for fresh air and exhaust systems
Air Duct Systems
General requirements for all ductwork
Low Capacity Systems
Specific requirements for residential and small commercial applications
Heating Appliances
Requirements for various heating equipment types
The Heating, Refrigeration and Air Conditioning 
Institute of Canada (HRAI)
HRAI (www.hrai.ca/) is a national non-profit trade association of heating, ventilation, air conditioning and refrigeration (HVACR) 
manufacturers, wholesalers, and contractors.
HRAI works with government departments at the local, provincial, and national levels to ensure that regulations reflect the expertise 
and concerns of those involved in the industry. The organization also provides training for the industry by conducting certification 
courses and publishing technical manuals.
Note: These courses do not authorize gas fitters/technicians to work on systems that exceed their local license based on the different 
existing trade regulations in various provinces but to offer additional avenues of training and awareness.
HRAI Ductwork Requirements
All ducting (except for bathroom fan ducts) must meet the requirements detailed in Part 6 
of the NBC. HRAI refers to four practical implications of Part 6 on ductwork:
Noncombustible 
Materials
Ducts must be made of 
noncombustible materials
Flexible Duct 
Standards
All flexible ducts must meet 
UL 181 Class 1 duct 
requirements
Proper Mounting
Ducts must be properly 
secured and mounted
Good Engineering
The design of ducting must 
be in accordance with good 
engineering practices
Heat Transfer, Ventilation, and Air Handlers
Air handlers are a key component of heating, cooling, and ventilation systems. A review of some of the key principles of heat 
transfer, heat loss/gain calculations, and ventilation requirements is necessary for a full appreciation of the role of air handlers. 
CSA Group Gas Trade Training especially Unit 14 The building as a system - covers most of these key principles.
Heat Transfer Fundamentals
Heat transfer is the process of heat moving from one source to another. 
The amount of heat contained in an object or substance depends upon 
its:
Temperature
The measure of thermal 
energy intensity
Weight
The mass of the substance
Specific Heat
The amount of heat required to raise the temperature of a unit 
weight of a substance one degree
Heat Transfer Terminology
Sensible Heat
Heat that changes the temperature of a substance without changing its state.
Latent Heat
Heat required to change the state of a substance without changing its 
temperature.
Total Heat (Enthalpy)
Sum of all the sensible heat and latent heat contained in a substance.
Specific Heat
Amount of heat required to raise the temperature of a unit weight of a 
substance one degree.
Specific Heat Measurements
Imperial Units
In imperial units, the measurement is in British Thermal 
Units (Btu). A Btu is the amount of heat required to change 
the temperature of one pound of water one degree 
Fahrenheit (1ºF).
The specific heat of water is 1 Btu in imperial units. It takes 
one Btu to raise one pound of water 1°F.
The specific heat of air varies slightly with temperature. At 
standard temperature, the specific heat is 0.2417 Btu/lb.
Metric Units
The calorie is the metric measurement used in the same way 
as the Btu. One calorie is equal to the amount of heat 
required to raise the temperature of one gram of water one 
degree Celsius.
A more commonly referenced metric unit of energy is the 
joule. One calorie is equal to 4.186 joules (J). Since it takes 1 
kilocalorie to raise the temperature of one kilogram of water 
1 °C, 4.186 kilojoules (kJ) will raise the temperature of one 
kilogram of water 1 °C.
In metric units, the specific heat of air is 1.01 kJ/kg.
Design Temperature 
Considerations
Indoor Design Temperature (IDT)
The temperature selected for the inside of the building — usually 72°F (22 °C) 
for buildings occupied by people.
Outdoor Design Temperature (ODT)
The expected outdoor temperature that a heating or cooling load must 
balance.
This temperature is based on a 10-year average for a specific location.
For heat loss calculations, it represents the lowest sustained temperature 
that might be expected during normal winter conditions.
For heat gain calculations, it is the highest sustained temperature that might 
be expected during normal summer conditions.
Heat Loss/Gain Calculation 
Factors
Variables
Data that relates to the location and specifications of a building.
Factors
Numerical values that represent the heat produced or transferred under a 
specific condition.
Exposed Surfaces
Building surfaces exposed to outdoor temperatures. These are calculated 
using the building dimensions. The area of each wall, roof, or other 
exposed surface is calculated separately.
Exposure
The direction a wall faces in relation to the elements.
Solar Gain and Wall Area Calculations
Solar Gain
Building heat gain associated with radiant heat from the sun. 
Solar gain on a surface depends on the exposure of the 
exterior walls, windows, and doors. Factors for solar gain are 
included in calculations of heating and cooling loads, 
according to different exposures of each flat surface to the 
sun.
The area of each flat surface is found by multiplying the 
length of the surface by the height.
Wall Area Calculations
Gross Wall Area: Total area of a wall, including windows, 
doors, and other openings. Gross wall area is calculated 
separ

CSA Unit 24 - Air Handling
Chapter 1                                           Air Handling for Gas Technicians
Since air movement has a significant impact on building comfort and safety, the gas technician/fitter must understand air handling. Gas technicians/fitters should be familiar with the building and gas codes, provincial regulations, and industry standards that govern air handling. In addition, they should have a good understanding of the effect of the building as a system on air movement, the process of heat transfer, and the qualities and characteristics of air.
MK
by Mike Kapin
Created
Copywrite 2025
Learning Objectives
Identify Codes and Standards
Identify codes and industry standards that apply to air flow
Understand Heat Transfer
Describe the process of heat transfer and heating equipment capacity
Air Properties
Describe the properties and characteristics of air
Service Procedures
Describe service and adjustment procedures for air handling units
Key Terminology
Abbreviation (Symbol)
Definition
H
The total heat contained in a substance, which is the sum of sensible heat and latent heat
The process of heat moving from one source to another
Moisture in the air that comes from water that has evaporated into the air
>
The volume of a substance per unit of the substance
The intensity of heat, measured with a dry bulb thermometer
V
The amount of space that a three-dimensional figure occupies
Gas Trade Training and Red Seal Alignment
You can use the CSA Group Gas Trade Training materials as resources to help you prepare for the Red Seal Gasfitter – Class B exam. For more information on how these materials align with the 2014 national standard for the occupation of Gasfitter - Class B, please review an expanded reference matrix at https://store.csagroup.org/.
Codes and Industry Standards
The gas technician/fitter must be familiar with the requirements contained in CSA B149.1 as well as the appropriate provincial building codes and industry standards. CSA Group publishes two standards directly relevant to air handling equipment:
CAN/CSA F280
Standard for determining the required capacity of residential space heating and cooling appliances
CAN/CSA F326
Standard for residential mechanical ventilation systems
HRAI and Industry Support
The Heating, Refrigeration and Air Conditioning Institute of Canada (HRAI) provides certification courses and technical manuals that address the requirements of building codes and industry standards for residential and small commercial heating, ventilating, and air conditioning systems, as they apply to selection and installation of these systems.
In addition to knowing building code requirements, the gas technician/fitter must consult with municipal building departments for local bylaws pertaining to heating and ventilation.
Relevant Codes and Standards
National Building Code of Canada (NBC)
National Building Code that forms the basis for codes written in Canadian provinces
National Research Council Canada (NRC): www.nrc-cnrc.gc.ca
Ontario Building Code (OBC)
Building code used in Ontario
Contains some additional requirements beyond CAN/CSA F326
Ontario Ministry of Municipal Affairs and Housing: www.mah.gov.on.ca
British Columbia Building Code (BCBC)
Building code used in British Columbia that contains some prescriptive requirements different from those of the NBC and CAN/CSA F326 (however, CAN/CSA F326 is permitted as an alternative.)
British Columbia Codes: www.bccodes.ca
R-2000 Standard
An industry-endorsed technical performance standard for energy efficiency, indoor air tightness quality, and environmental responsibility in home construction
Technical requirements comply with CAN/CSA F326, but include additional requirements for energy performance, qualifications of the installer and designer, and record-keeping
A voluntary standard administered by Natural Resources Canada (NRCan): www.nrcan.gc.ca/home
National Building Code of Canada (NBC)
Two sections of the NBC contain clauses that apply to air handlers:
Part 6
Heating, Ventilating and Air-Conditioning
Covers technical requirements
Applies to all buildings
Part 9
Housing and Small Buildings
Covers prescriptive requirements
Applies to buildings of three or fewer stories and with a building area not exceeding 600 m²
NBC Application Areas
Besides general clauses dealing with scope, application, definitions, and plans and specifications, Parts 6 and 9 apply to design and installation of:
Ventilation
Requirements for fresh air and exhaust systems
Air Duct Systems
General requirements for all ductwork
Low Capacity Systems
Specific requirements for residential and small commercial applications
Heating Appliances
Requirements for various heating equipment types
The Heating, Refrigeration and Air Conditioning Institute of Canada (HRAI)
HRAI (www.hrai.ca/) is a national non-profit trade association of heating, ventilation, air conditioning and refrigeration (HVACR) manufacturers, wholesalers, and contractors.
HRAI works with government departments at the local, provincial, and national levels to ensure that regulations reflect the expertise and concerns of those involved in the industry. The organization also provides training for the industry by conducting certification courses and publishing technical manuals.
Note: These courses do not authorize gas fitters/technicians to work on systems that exceed their local license based on the different existing trade regulations in various provinces but to offer additional avenues of training and awareness.
HRAI Ductwork Requirements
All ducting (except for bathroom fan ducts) must meet the requirements detailed in Part 6 of the NBC. HRAI refers to four practical implications of Part 6 on ductwork:
Noncombustible Materials
Ducts must be made of noncombustible materials
Flexible Duct Standards
All flexible ducts must meet UL 181 Class 1 duct requirements
Proper Mounting
Ducts must be properly secured and mounted
Good Engineering
The design of ducting must be in accordance with good engineering practices
Heat Transfer, Ventilation, and Air Handlers
Air handlers are a key component of heating, cooling, and ventilation systems. A review of some of the key principles of heat transfer, heat loss/gain calculations, and ventilation requirements is necessary for a full appreciation of the role of air handlers. CSA Group Gas Trade Training especially Unit 14 The building as a system - covers most of these key principles.
Heat Transfer Fundamentals
Heat transfer is the process of heat moving from one source to another. The amount of heat contained in an object or substance depends upon its:
Temperature
The measure of thermal energy intensity
Weight
The mass of the substance
Specific Heat
The amount of heat required to raise the temperature of a unit weight of a substance one degree
Heat Transfer Terminology
Sensible Heat
Heat that changes the temperature of a substance without changing its state.
Latent Heat
Heat required to change the state of a substance without changing its temperature.
Total Heat (Enthalpy)
Sum of all the sensible heat and latent heat contained in a substance.
Specific Heat
Amount of heat required to raise the temperature of a unit weight of a substance one degree.
Specific Heat Measurements
Imperial Units
In imperial units, the measurement is in British Thermal Units (Btu). A Btu is the amount of heat required to change the temperature of one pound of water one degree Fahrenheit (1ºF).
The specific heat of water is 1 Btu in imperial units. It takes one Btu to raise one pound of water 1°F.
The specific heat of air varies slightly with temperature. At standard temperature, the specific heat is 0.2417 Btu/lb.
Metric Units
The calorie is the metric measurement used in the same way as the Btu. One calorie is equal to the amount of heat required to raise the temperature of one gram of water one degree Celsius.
A more commonly referenced metric unit of energy is the joule. One calorie is equal to 4.186 joules (J). Since it takes 1 kilocalorie to raise the temperature of one kilogram of water 1 °C, 4.186 kilojoules (kJ) will raise the temperature of one kilogram of water 1 °C.
In metric units, the specific heat of air is 1.01 kJ/kg.
Design Temperature Considerations
Indoor Design Temperature (IDT)
The temperature selected for the inside of the building — usually 72°F (22 °C) for buildings occupied by people.
Outdoor Design Temperature (ODT)
The expected outdoor temperature that a heating or cooling load must balance.
This temperature is based on a 10-year average for a specific location.
For heat loss calculations, it represents the lowest sustained temperature that might be expected during normal winter conditions.
For heat gain calculations, it is the highest sustained temperature that might be expected during normal summer conditions.
Heat Loss/Gain Calculation Factors
Variables
Data that relates to the location and specifications of a building.
Factors
Numerical values that represent the heat produced or transferred under a specific condition.
Exposed Surfaces
Building surfaces exposed to outdoor temperatures. These are calculated using the building dimensions. The area of each wall, roof, or other exposed surface is calculated separately.
Exposure
The direction a wall faces in relation to the elements.
Solar Gain and Wall Area Calculations
Solar Gain
Building heat gain associated with radiant heat from the sun. Solar gain on a surface depends on the exposure of the exterior walls, windows, and doors. Factors for solar gain are included in calculations of heating and cooling loads, according to different exposures of each flat surface to the sun.
The area of each flat surface is found by multiplying the length of the surface by the height.
Wall Area Calculations
Gross Wall Area: Total area of a wall, including windows, doors, and other openings. Gross wall area is calculated separately for each exposed wall of a building.
Net Wall Area: Area of a wall after the areas of windows, d

documents.filename: CSA Unit 24 Air Handling - Question Bank.docx
documents.content:
CSA Unit 24 Air Handling - 90 Question Multiple Choice Test
Instructions
Choose the best answer for each question. Mark your answers clearly.
1. Which CSA standard determines the required capacity of residential space heating and cooling appliances? A) CSA B149.1 B) CAN/CSA F280 C) CAN/CSA F326 D) CSA F327
2. What does HRAI stand for? A) Heating, Refrigeration and Air Conditioning Institute of Canada B) Home Renovation and Air Installation Corporation C) Heat Recovery and Air Intelligence D) Housing Retrofit Air Integration
3. According to the NBC, Part 6 covers which requirements? A) Prescriptive requirements for small buildings B) Technical requirements for heating, ventilating and air-conditioning C) Electrical requirements for HVAC systems D) Plumbing requirements for air handlers
4. What material standard must all flexible ducts meet according to HRAI? A) UL 181 Class 2 B) UL 181 Class 1 C) CSA Class A D) NBC Class 3
5. Heat transfer is defined as: A) The temperature of a substance B) The process of heat moving from one source to another C) The weight of heated air D) The volume of air in a system
6. What is sensible heat? A) Heat that changes the state of a substance without changing temperature B) Heat that changes temperature without changing the state C) The total heat in a substance D) Heat required to vaporize water
7. In imperial units, what is the specific heat of air at standard temperature? A) 1.0 Btu/lb B) 0.2417 Btu/lb C) 0.5 Btu/lb D) 1.08 Btu/lb
8. What is the typical indoor design temperature for buildings occupied by people? A) 68°F (20°C) B) 70°F (21°C) C) 72°F (22°C) D) 75°F (24°C)
9. Which method of heat transfer occurs when heat flows through a material from the warmer side to the cooler side? A) Convection B) Radiation C) Conduction D) Evaporation
10. What is the primary function of a space-heating appliance according to the text? A) To create positive building pressure B) To replace heat lost by the building C) To circulate air throughout the building D) To filter indoor air
11. Which ventilation system creates negative pressure in a building? A) Supply fan systems B) Balanced systems C) Exhaust fan systems D) Integrated systems
12. What problem can occur with supply fan ventilation systems in winter? A) Back-drafting of appliances B) Cold air blowing directly on occupants C) Excessive negative pressure D) Reduced air quality
13. What type of distribution system uses the forced-air heating system to distribute ventilation air? A) Dedicated distribution B) Through-the-wall distribution C) Integrated distribution D) Independent distribution
14. What is relative humidity? A) The actual amount of moisture in air B) The temperature at which moisture condenses C) The amount of moisture in air compared to maximum capacity at the same temperature D) The weight of water vapor per pound of dry air
15. At what condition do dry bulb and wet bulb temperatures become equal? A) At maximum humidity B) At dew point (saturation) C) At standard conditions D) At zero humidity
16. What is enthalpy? A) The temperature of air B) The moisture content of air C) The total heat contained in a substance D) The volume of air per unit weight
17. At standard conditions, what is the volume of one pound of dry air? A) 12.5 ft³ B) 13.33 ft³ C) 14.7 ft³ D) 15.2 ft³
18. For residential applications requiring 1.5 air changes per hour, what is the imperial calculation formula? A) cfm = Volume × 1.5 × 60 B) cfm = Volume × 1.5 ÷ 60 C) cfm = Volume ÷ 1.5 × 60 D) cfm = Volume × 60 ÷ 1.5
19. What is the typical minimum airflow rate for a 2-bedroom home under 140 m² according to the building code table? A) 14 L/s B) 21 L/s C) 28 L/s D) 35 L/s
20. Which type of blower blade is most common in residential applications? A) Backward-curved B) Forward-curved C) Airfoil D) Straight
21. What does ECM stand for? A) Electric Control Motor B) Electronically Commutated Motor C) Energy Conservation Motor D) Electronic Current Motor
22. Which motor type provides variable speed capability with high efficiency? A) PSC motor B) Shaded pole motor C) ECM motor D) Split-phase motor
23. What should be done with filters according to maintenance requirements? A) Clean monthly, replace annually B) Replace according to manufacturer specifications and usage C) Clean only when visibly dirty D) Replace every six months regardless of condition
24. What tool measures air velocity at supply registers? A) Manometer B) Anemometer C) Flow hood D) Pitot tube
25. What is the most common cause of inefficient heating and cooling system operation? A) Undersized ductwork B) Improper damper position C) Dirty air filtration devices D) Blocked cooling coils
26. In an extended plenum system, what are the small ducts called that deliver air to rooms? A) Trunk ducts B) Branch ducts C) Return ducts D) Supply ducts
27. What happens to trunk duct size in a reducing plenum system? A) Stays the same throughout B) Gets larger as branches are added C) Gets smaller as branches are added D) Alternates between large and small sections
28. Which return air system is more expensive but provides the most positive return? A) Central return B) Individual return C) Perimeter return D) Radial return
29. What is a take-off in duct systems? A) A transition piece B) A fitting that draws air from a plenum into another duct C) A damper control device D) An outlet grille
30. What should be installed to ensure gradual changes in duct volume? A) Take-offs B) Dampers C) Transition fittings D) Drive cleats
31. What is the purpose of dampers in duct systems? A) To connect different sized ducts B) To control the flow of air C) To reduce noise D) To prevent heat loss
32. Which side of duct liner should face the air stream? A) White side B) Silver side C) Black side D) Either side
33. What is the primary purpose of flexible duct connectors? A) To connect different sized ducts B) To allow for thermal expansion C) To reduce noise transmission D) To improve air flow
34. Where should air filtration devices be located in relation to humidifiers? A) Downstream from humidifiers B) Upstream from humidifiers C) Parallel to humidifiers D) It doesn't matter
35. What is gauge pressure? A) Pressure above perfect vacuum B) Pressure at standard conditions C) Amount by which pressure exceeds ambient atmospheric pressure D) Pressure measured in mercury
36. For very small pressure changes in forced-air systems, measurements are typically expressed in: A) Pounds per square inch (psi) B) Inches of water column (w.c.) C) Kilopascals (kPa) D) Millimeters of mercury
37. What is the typical airflow requirement per ton of cooling? A) 300 cfm B) 400 cfm C) 500 cfm D) 600 cfm
38. In the air flow calculation formula V = Q/A, what does 'A' represent? A) Air velocity B) Air flow rate C) Area of duct D) Atmospheric pressure
39. What is static pressure? A) Air pressure parallel to air flow direction B) Air pressure perpendicular to air flow direction C) Total pressure minus velocity pressure D) Pressure created by air weight
40. How is velocity pressure calculated? A) Static pressure + Total pressure B) Total pressure - Static pressure C) Static pressure × 2 D) Total pressure ÷ Static pressure
41. What device uses two concentric tubes to measure velocity pressure? A) Manometer B) Anemometer C) Pitot tube D) Flow hood
42. For accurate pitot tube readings, how far downstream from elbows should measurements be taken? A) 5 duct diameters B) 10 duct diameters C) 15 duct diameters D) 20 duct diameters
43. In the air velocity formula V = 4005 × √Pv, what does the constant 4005 represent? A) Conversion factor for imperial units B) Standard atmospheric pressure C) Air density at standard conditions D) Gravitational constant
44. What is the typical maximum external static pressure for furnace operation? A) 0.25 inch w.c. B) 0.50 inch w.c. C) 0.75 inch w.c. D) 1.00 inch w.c.
45. In the static pressure drop formula TPD = (L/100) × DPD, what does 'L' represent? A) Length of duct section in feet B) Load factor C) Loss coefficient D) Linear velocity
46. When sizing a blower, what must be calculated to determine total static pressure drop? A) Only supply side pressure drop B) Only return side pressure drop C) Supply and return side pressure drops added together D) Average of supply and return pressure drops
47. What size drill bit is used for static pressure test holes? A) 1/4 inch B) 5/16 inch C) 3/8 inch D) 1/2 inch
48. If supply static pressure is 0.26 inch w.c. and return static pressure is 0.21 inch w.c., what is the TESP? A) 0.05 inch w.c. B) 0.47 inch w.c. C) 0.235 inch w.c. D) 0.52 inch w.c.
49. In the heating air flow formula AF = OR / (1.08 × TR), what does the constant 1.08 represent? A) Standard air density B) Heat capacity factor C) Conversion constant D) Efficiency factor
50. How long should a furnace run to reach steady-state efficiency for temperature rise measurement? A) 5 minutes B) 10 minutes C) 15 minutes D) 20 minutes
51. If temperature rise is higher than specified, what adjustment should be made? A) Decrease blower speed B) Increase blower speed C) Adjust gas pressure D) Change burner orifices
52. What can significantly impact fan performance besides motor condition? A) Ambient temperature only B) Voltage, cleanliness, and duct configuration C) Only electrical connections D) Time of day operation
53. What is the most common cause of reduced air flow in HVAC systems? A) Worn motors B) Dirty filters C) Loose belts D) Misaligned pulleys
54. Gas-fired duct furnaces are designed for use with: A) Built-in air handlers only B) Separate air handling devices C) Natural draft venting only D) Residential applications only
55. Where are indoor duct furnaces typically installed? A) In basements B) Suspended from main roof beams C) On exterior walls D) In utility rooms
56. What type of venting uses a fan to force combustion gases out? A) Natural draft vented B) Power vented C) Direct vented D) Induced draft vented
57. What mounting option

Gas Trade Training – Chapter Questions 
Updated: November 2019 
 
 
© 2019 Canadian Standards Association 
 
1 
Unit 24 – Chapter 01: Heat loss/Heat gain 
 
1. Which type of ventilation system can lead to problems with moisture laden air being driven 
onto the wall cavities? 
a) Natural ventilation 
b) Balanced ventilation 
c) Supply fan ventilation 
d) Exhaust fan ventilation 
 
2. Which type of ventilation system can cause problems with the venting action of fuel-fired 
appliances, creating combustion product spillage or back-drafting? 
a) Natural ventilation 
b) Balanced ventilation 
c) Supply fan ventilation 
d) Exhaust fan ventilation 
 
3. What is enthalpy? 
a) Enthalpy is the dew point of a sample of air 
b) Enthalpy is the total heat contained in a substance 
c) Enthalpy is the latent heat contained in a substance 
d) Enthalpy is the sensible heat contained in a substance 
 
4. What is dewpoint? 
a) The temperature required to change the state of a substance  
b) The temperature based on a 10year average for a specific location 
c) The temperature below which moisture in the air begins to condense 
d) The temperature above which moisture in the air begins to condense
Gas Trade Training – Chapter Questions 
Updated: November 2019 
 
 
© 2019 Canadian Standards Association 
 
2 
5. What is the term that describes the percentage of moisture in the air compared to the 
amount it would hold if the air were saturated at the same temperature? 
a) Dew point 
b) Humidity ratio 
c) Relative humidity 
d) Wet bulb temperature 
 
6. What is the term that indicates the actual amount of moisture found in the air? 
a) Dew point 
b) Humidity ratio 
c) Relative humidity 
d) Wet bulb temperature 
 
7. When the temperature on two sides of a material is different, heat flows from the cooler 
side to the warmer side. 
a) True 
b) False 
 
8. What is the specific heat of air at standard conditions? 
a) 0.018 Btu/lb 
b) 0.2417 Btu/lb 
c) 1.01 Btu/lb 
d) 4.186 Btu/lb 
 
9. What is the danger of having too little ventilation in a dwelling? 
a) Increased costs 
b) Cool and Drafty 
c) Positive building pressures 
d) A buildup of pollutants within the dwelling

Gas Trade Training – Chapter Questions 
Updated: November 2019 
 
 
© 2019 Canadian Standards Association 
 
1 
Unit 24 – Chapter 02: Air handling units 
 
1. What is the proper position of a gas fired duct furnace? 
a) Upstream of air conditioning coil and air handling fan 
b) Downstream of air conditioning coil and air handling fan 
c) Upstream of air conditioning coil and downstream of air handling fan 
d) Downstream of air conditioning coil and upstream of air handling fan 
 
2. If multiple separately controlled and sequenced duct furnaces are installed in series within 
the same duct, the upstream duct furnaces must operate before the downstream duct 
furnaces. 
a) True 
b) False 
 
3. A radial duct system can be used to increase headroom in a basement. 
a) True 
b) False 
 
4. On individual return air systems, what is usually done to ensure less resistance to air flow in 
the return system? 
a) Undercut doors 
b) Slightly larger return air ducts 
c) Slightly smaller return air ducts 
d) Include return air grilles in rooms without supply air 
 
5. Paint can make flexible duct connectors rigid and prevent them from absorbing vibration. 
a) True 
b) False

6. What would indicate internal blockages may be present with a duct furnace? cycling on and 
off due to the operation of the high temperature limit control or incorrect temperature rise 
across the heat exchanger. 
a) Increased CFM 
b) Decreased temperature rise 
c) Increase motor current draw 
d) Cycling on and off on high limit 
 
7. If the blower in a forced-air distribution system moves 2100 cfm of air through a 24 inch x 
18 inch duct? 
a) 58 ft/min 
b) 420 ft/min 
c) 700 ft/min 
d) 1000 ft/min 
 
8. Select the statement that best defines velocity pressure. 
a) Decrease in air pressure caused by friction 
b) Pressure that is created by the air movement  
c) Pressure against which the blower has to work 
d) Air pressure in the duct at right angles to the direction of air flow 
 
9. Where is the lowest air pressure in the ductwork of a forced air heating system? 
a) On the supply side after the cooling coil 
b) On the return side upstream of the filter 
c) On the return side between the furnace and the filter 
d) On the supply side between the furnace and the cooling coil 
 
10. If the flanges are closed on an adjustable motor pulley, what happens to the belt and pulley? 
a) Belt is raised and pulley diameter gets larger 
b) Belt is raised and pulley diameter gets smaller 
c) Belt is lowered and pulley diameter gets larger 
d) Belt is lowered and pulley diameter gets smaller

b) ½ the original blower speed 
c) Twice the original blower speed 
d) Four times the original blower speed

temperature rise across the heat exchanger? 
a) Air flow would increase and temperature rise would decrease 
b) Air flow would decrease and temperature rise would increase

a) Less work done by motor so current decreases 
b) Less work done by motor so current increases  
c) More work done by motor so current increases  
d) More work done by motor so current decreases 
 
14. A PSC motor with multiple windings gets lower efficiency at lower speeds 
a) True 
b) False 
 
15. An ECM maintains an efficiency range between 60% and 80%for all speeds 
a) True 
b) False

a) 566 ft/min 
b) 801 ft/min 
c) 1132 ft/min 
d) 1602 ft/min

a) Natural ventilation 
b) Balanced ventilation 
c) Supply fan ventilation

b) Enthalpy is the total heat contained in a substance 
c) Enthalpy is the latent heat contained in a substance 
d) Enthalpy is the sensible heat contained in a substance

a) The temperature required to change the state of a substance  
b) The temperature based on a 10year average for a specific location 
c) The temperature below which moisture in the air begins to condense 
d) The temperature above which moisture in the air begins to condense

Blower Replacement Practical
Learning Outcome:
Upon completion of this shop project, you will understand how to remove the blower housing from a furnace, remove and replace the motor, and then reinstall the blower housing.
Instructions:
Verify with the instructor which furnace to work on. Follow the steps below to complete the removal, replacement, and reinstallation of a motor.
Note: Each step must be signed off by the instructor before proceeding to the next question. Skipped sign offs will result in lost marks (2 per). Any damage to the systems components due to negligence or horseplay will result in a mark of zero for the practical.
Follow all shop safety rules.

Furnace Air Pressure
Readings Project
Learning Outcome:
Identify normal and abnormal operating conditions associated with    a forced warm air furnace.
Instructions:
You will be utilizing a manometer and furnace to measure and record air pressure readings. Testing will show normal and abnormal operating conditions at various points due to air flow restriction.
Note: Each step must be signed off by the instructor before proceeding to the next question. Skipped sign offs will result in lost marks (2 per). Any damage to the systems components due to negligence or horseplay will result in a mark of zero for the practical.
Follow all shop safety rules.
General Airflow Information:
Static pressure is measured to interpret airflow in a duct system. Generally, manufacturers engineering manuals rate airflow in furnaces and air handlers based on Total External Static Pressure or TESP. A typical furnace is designed to operate around 0.50 “W.C. If there is more than 0.50 inches TESP, the fan may not be moving the required air flow. You should always carefully check the fan capacity of the furnaces and air handlers you select. The pressure capacities will range from .05 ‐ to 1.0 “W.C.
Static Pressure Testing:
To determine the TESP of a furnace you first measure the supply (+positive) pressure. This should be near the discharge of the unit, between the furnace and AC coil (test point C). Next, you measure the return (–negative) pressure. This should be near the inlet of the unit, often between the filter and the furnace (test point B). Now take the two pressures and add them together to determine the system’s TESP. When adding the positive and negative pressures together ignore the + and – signs. These only indicate the type of pressure measured. Compare the measured TESP to the rated pressure found on the appliance rating plate or in the manual.
Using the diagram above as a guide, attach your manometer to the system and take the required measurements. For any test points that are unclear, verify with the instructor.    (15 marks)
With the furnace set to heating:
With the furnace set to cooling:
With the furnace set to fan only:
Sign off: ____________________
What was the Total External Static Pressure as indicated on Rating plate and how did it compare with your readings under normal and restricted conditions? (2 marks)
_________________________________________________________________________________________________________________________________________________________________________________________________________________________________
What effect would a higher vs lower fan speed, or larger vs smaller ductwork have on your readings? (2 marks)
____________________________________________________________________________________________________________________________________________________________________________________________________________________________________________________________________________________________________________
Pressure drop across the air filter is determined by measuring the pressure on each side of a filter and then subtracting the two pressures to find the pressure difference. Follow the table below to check the different pressure drops across the different scenarios: (9 marks)
Sign off: ____________________
Measured blower amperage reading with no restriction: _______________
Measured blower amperage reading with full restriction: _______________
What effect did a blocked filter have on the operation of the furnace? (2 marks)
_________________________________________________________________________________________________________________________________________________________________________________________________________________________________
What effect did a blocked filter have on the amperage draw of the blower motor? (2 marks)
___________________________________________________________________________
Pressure drop across the coil is determined by measuring the pressure on each side of the coil and then subtracting one pressure from the other to find the pressure difference. Coil pressure drop can be compared to the manufacturer’s rated coil pressure drop at current airflow to determine if coil is clean. Follow the table below to check the different pressure drops across the different scenarios: (9 marks)
Sign off: ____________________

Furnace Air Pressure
Readings Project
Learning Outcome:
Identify normal and abnormal operating conditions associated with    a forced warm air furnace.
Instructions:
You will be utilizing a manometer and furnace to measure and record air pressure readings. Testing will show normal and abnormal operating conditions at various points due to air flow restriction.
Note: Each step must be signed off by the instructor before proceeding to the next question. Skipped sign offs will result in lost marks (5 per). Any damage to the systems components due to negligence or horseplay will result in a mark of zero for the practical.
Follow all shop safety rules.
Static Pressure Testing:
To determine the TESP of a furnace, you must measure the supply (positive) pressure, and the return (negative) pressure. The supply must be measured near the discharge of the unit, after the AC coil (test point D). The return must be measured near the inlet of the unit, before the filter (test point A). Now take the two measurements and add them together (ignore the + and –) to determine the system’s TESP. Compare the measured TESP to the rated pressure found on the appliance rating plate or in the manual.
Using the diagram above as a guide, attach your manometer to the system and take the required measurements. For any test points that are unclear, verify with the instructor.    (15 marks per table)
Heating
Cooling
Fan Only

____________________________________________________________________________________________________________________________________________________________________________________________________________________________________________________________________________________________________________

_______________________________________________________________________________________________________________________________________________________________________________________________________________________________________________________________________________________________________________________________________________________________________________________
Pressure drop across the air filter is determined by measuring the pressure on each side of a filter and then subtracting the two pressures to find the difference. Follow the table below to check the different pressure drops across the different scenarios: (9 marks)
Sign off: ____________________
Measured blower amperage reading with no restriction: _______________
Measured blower amperage reading with full restriction: _______________
What effect did a blocked filter have on the operation of the furnace? (2 marks)
____________________________________________________________________________________________________________________________________________________________________________________________________________________________________________________________________________________________________________
What effect did a blocked filter have on the amperage draw of the blower motor? (2 marks)
____________________________________________________________________________________________________________________________________________________________________________________________________________________________________________________________________________________________________________
Pressure drop across the coil is determined by measuring the pressure on each side of the coil and then subtracting the two pressures to find the difference. This measurement can be compared to the manufacturer’s rated pressure to determine if the coil is clean. Follow the table below to check the different pressure drops across the different scenarios: (9 marks)
